replication_study.hypothesis: At the country level, the democracy index is positively associated with confirmed COVID-19 cases per one million people (operationalized as cases_per_million on 2020-04-03 regressed on democracy, controlling for average yearly temperature and economic openness).

data_plan.source_type: Compiled cross-country database assembled from public sources (ECDC COVID case counts; World Bank trade measures; annual temperature from meteoblue/indexmundi; democracy index from EIU/Gapminder)
data_plan.wave_or_subset: Cross-sectional snapshot corresponding to confirmed COVID-19 cases through 03-Apr-2020 (variable in the dataset identified as COVID.12.31_04.03 / COVID_12_31_04_03 pattern). The provided replication dataset also contains other time frames, but the planned replication uses the April 3, 2020 snapshot to match the original study.
data_plan.sample_size: Final sample size will be the number of countries with non-missing values for cases_per_million, democracy, temperature, and openness after preprocessing. The original paper reported 163 countries; the provided replication file contains a similar cross-national set (the exact N will be reported after executing the preprocessing step; expected N ≈ 160–170).
data_plan.access_details: Data file included with the study package at ./data/original/3/python/replication_data/COVID replication.dta. The original external sources cited in post_registration.json and the paper are public (ECDC, World Bank, meteoblue, indexmundi, Economist Intelligence Unit). No extra access restrictions specified for the provided file.

qualification.explanation: The provided dataset is qualified for replication because it contains the same operationalized outcome (confirmed COVID-19 cases per one million as of 2020-04-03), the same democracy index variable (originally from EIU and available in the .dta), the same annual temperature measure, and trade/openness measures used in the original paper. The replication data are an independent packaged dataset derived from the same public sources and therefore suitable for checking robustness of the original cross-country association.
qualification.similarity_to_original: The match to the original is high-fidelity: the post-registration and paper specify the outcome as cases per million on April 3, 2020 and list democracy index, temperature, and openness as main regressors (see ./data/original/3/python/post_registration.json and ./data/original/3/python/original_paper.pdf). The replication .dta includes variables matching those names/patterns (see the raw .dta content in ./data/original/3/python/replication_data/COVID replication.dta and the .do-file mapping in ./data/original/3/python/replication_data/Hossain 2020 - Replication Analysis.do).
qualification.deviation_from_original: Deviations are minimal and explicit: the replication .dta contains multiple COVID time-frame variables (e.g., COVID.12.31_04.03, COVID.12.31_08.11, COVID.04.04_08.11) while the original focal snapshot is the 04-03-2020 value — the replication will explicitly select the 04-03-2020 column to match the original (see the .do-file logic in ./data/original/3/python/replication_data/Hossain 2020 - Replication Analysis.do). Also, the democracy index in the .dta appears to be Gapminder-scaled (0-100) and the provided .do divides by 10 to match the EIU 0-10 scale; the Python translation replicates that same transformation (see the renaming/division in the .do and implemented in ./data/original/3/python/replication_data/Hossain_Replication__py.py). These steps preserve fidelity while correctly mapping variable encodings.
qualification.references: Original/preregistration statements: ./data/original/3/python/post_registration.json and ./data/original/3/python/original_paper.pdf. Variable mappings and transformations: ./data/original/3/python/replication_data/Hossain 2020 - Replication Analysis.do. Replication dataset provided: ./data/original/3/python/replication_data/COVID replication.dta. Python translation: ./data/original/3/python/replication_data/Hossain_Replication__py.py.

data_plan.notes: Be aware of minor name/encoding differences in the .dta (columns use dots/underscores and some descriptive labels like 'Democracy index (EIU)', 'COVID.12.31_04.03', 'popData2019', 'Annual_temp', 'trade.2016'). The Python script searches by pattern to locate these columns. The dataset may contain NA/missing values and non-numeric encodings for some columns. The provided package contains the original Stata .do and the translated Python script (we keep the original files unchanged and the translation as Hossain_Replication__py.py). All IO by the replication script writes and reads under /app/data as required.

steps: 1) Read the provided replication .dta at /app/data/original/3/python/replication_data/COVID replication.dta.
2) Select the column corresponding to cumulative COVID confirmed cases up to 2020-04-03 (the script searches for COVID.12.31_04.03 / COVID_12_31_04_03 patterns) and name it total_cases.
3) Use population (popData2019) to compute cases_per_million = total_cases / popData2019 * 1,000,000.
4) Identify and coerce democracy, annual temperature, and trade/openness columns to numeric. Apply the same democracy rescaling used in the original .do (divide by 10 if the index is on 0-100 scale).
5) Drop rows with missing values on the variables required for the focal regression (listwise deletion). Record final N.
6) Estimate OLS: cases_per_million ~ democracy + temperature + openness (with constant) using statsmodels OLS.
7) Save regression summary (text) and coefficients/p-values (JSON) under /app/data for inspection and comparison with original reported coefficients.
8) Optionally run sensitivity checks (e.g., alternative COVID time windows that are present in the .dta) following the .do-file options.
planned_method.models: Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) linear regression. Primary specification: cases_per_million = beta0 + beta1*d(emocracy) + beta2*temperature + beta3*openness + error.
planned_method.outcome_variable: cases_per_million (confirmed COVID-19 cases per 1,000,000 population; computed from the COVID cumulative cases column and popData2019).
planned_method.independent_variables: Primary: democracy (rescaled to 0-10 if needed), average yearly temperature (Annual_temp/temperature), economic openness (trade_2016 / trade.2016 / imputed_trade / trade.recent).
planned_method.control_variables: The focal replication mirrors the original which treated precipitation and population density as initially considered but then excluded when insignificance was found; primary controls are temperature and openness. Additional diagnostics (heteroscedasticity, normality) may be run for robustness.
planned_method.tools_software: Python 3 (script using pandas and statsmodels). The original used Excel/STATA/EViews, but the replication uses Python for reproducibility. Files: ./data/original/3/python/replication_data/Hossain_Replication__py.py (executable entrypoint).

planned_estimation_and_test.estimation: Estimate coefficient values (beta) for democracy, temperature, and openness; report point estimates, standard errors, p-values, and adjusted R-squared.
planned_estimation_and_test.test: t-tests on each coefficient (two-sided) to evaluate significance; compare sign and magnitude qualitatively to original results and report p-values. For the focal claim, specific interest is the sign and statistical significance of the democracy coefficient.

planned_method.missing_data_handling: Listwise deletion (drop any country with missing values among outcome and focal regressors). The replication will record the pre/post-drop sample sizes.
planned_method.multiple_testing_policy: No additional multiple-testing corrections planned for the primary focal test (single primary hypothesis on democracy). If multiple hypotheses or multiple outcomes are formally tested, a Bonferroni or Benjamini-Hochberg correction will be reported as sensitivity.
planned_method.inference_criteria: Primary inference: statistical significance at alpha = 0.05 (two-sided). Directionality matters: for the focal claim we expect a positive coefficient on democracy. Report exact p-values and interpret with caution given cross-sectional observational design and potential measurement/reporting biases.

files.replication_data/Hossain_Replication__py: Translated and executable Python script that replicates the core analysis of the original Stata .do. It locates the April 3, 2020 COVID cases column in the provided .dta, computes cases_per_million, rescales the democracy index as in the original .do (divide by 10), coerces/reads temperature and trade/openness variables, runs OLS (statsmodels), and writes outputs to /app/data (Hossain_Replication_results.txt and Hossain_Replication_coefs.json). This is the entrypoint to run the replication in this package.
files.replication_data/Hossain 2020 - Replicat: Original Stata .do included for reference; not executed in the container. The Python script implements the .do's logic. The .do maps variable names and documents the choice to divide the democracy index by 10.
files.replication_data/COVID replication.dta: Input dataset used by the replication script. The script expects this file at /app/data/original/3/python/replication_data/COVID replication.dta (reads via pandas.read_stata).

codebase.notes: I translated the original Stata workflow into Python per the replication-run policy. The Python script (Hossain_Replication__py.py) reads and writes exclusively under /app/data and the replication_data subfolder under the study path. Dependencies: pandas and statsmodels. The original .do remains unchanged; the Python file is a new executable that preserves the original analysis logic including the democracy rescaling. If someone wishes to re-run the original Stata .do instead, they'd need STATA and an appropriate working directory; the translation is intended to be self-contained for the environment described here.

analysis.instructions: 1) Ensure the dataset COVID replication.dta is at /app/data/original/3/python/replication_data/COVID replication.dta. 2) Install dependencies (pandas, statsmodels, pyreadstat). 3) Run the Python entrypoint: python /app/data/original/3/python/replication_data/Hossain_Replication__py.py. 4) The script will write a text summary to /app/data/Hossain_Replication_results.txt and a JSON of coefficients/p-values to /app/data/Hossain_Replication_coefs.json. 5) Compare the democracy coefficient sign, point estimate, and p-value to the original reported democracy coefficient (86.76467 in the original paper / post-registration). Report differences in sign, magnitude, and significance and note sample size used after listwise deletion.
analysis.comparison_metrics: Compare (a) coefficient on democracy: sign and magnitude, (b) p-value for democracy coefficient, (c) standard error of the democracy coefficient, (d) adjusted R-squared, and (e) sample size (N after listwise deletion). Also record the coefficients for temperature and openness for context.
